opportunities.title: AI in RevOps: Where It Helps Today (and Where It Quietly Makes Data Worse)
opportunities.angle: Contrarian take: AI doesn’t fix broken data; it amplifies it. Outline high-confidence use cases (dedupe suggestions, enrichment validation, call summarization QA) vs. risky ones (auto-updating CRM fields without governance).

opportunities.title: The Hidden Cost of “One More Tool”: A RevOps ROI Framework for Consolidation vs. Integration
opportunities.angle: Tool sprawl isn’t just license cost—it’s reconciliation time, broken automations, and inconsistent attribution. Provide a simple ROI model to decide: consolidate, integrate, or retire—based on data criticality and workflow dependency.

opportunities.title: The RevOps Data Contract: A Practical Spec for Lead, Account, and Opportunity Fields
opportunities.angle: Most “data quality” initiatives fail because they’re vague. Define a RevOps data contract (field definitions, allowed values, ownership, SLAs, and change control) so every system and team aligns on what each object/field means—and automation stops breaking silently.

opportunities.title: RevOps Observability: The Missing Layer for Catching Broken Routing, Sync Failures, and Silent Data Drift
opportunities.angle: Treat RevOps like production systems: you need monitoring, alerts, and audit trails. Explain what to instrument (lead routing latency, sync error rates, field drift, enrichment failures) and how observability prevents revenue-impacting incidents.

opportunities.title: Stop Building Dashboards: Build a Revenue Source of Truth (and Let Dashboards Be a Byproduct)
opportunities.angle: Dashboards don’t create alignment; shared definitions and governed pipelines do. The thesis: invest first in a unified revenue data model + transformation layer, then dashboards become consistent across Finance, Sales, and CS without constant rework.

opportunities.title: The RevOps Automation Maturity Model: From “Zapier Chaos” to Governed Workflows
opportunities.angle: Automation often starts as quick fixes and becomes brittle. Map a maturity model (ad hoc → standardized → governed → observable) and show what to implement at each stage: naming conventions, versioning, testing, monitoring, and ownership.

opportunities.title: Forecasting Without Heroics: A Simple Method to Reconcile CRM, Billing, and Product Usage
opportunities.angle: Forecast accuracy improves when CRM is reconciled with billing and product signals. Share a method to align definitions (bookings vs. revenue), handle renewals/expansions, and create a reconciliation cadence that Finance trusts.

opportunities.title: The 30-Minute RevOps Audit: 10 Questions That Reveal Your Biggest Data Silo Risks
opportunities.angle: A fast diagnostic that surfaces where silos are hurting revenue operations: duplicate accounts, inconsistent lifecycle stages, missing ownership, broken routing, unmonitored automations, and conflicting definitions across teams.

opportunities.title: Pipeline Hygiene That Actually Predicts Revenue: 7 Rules You Can Enforce Automatically
opportunities.angle: Most pipeline hygiene is subjective and unenforced. Define objective rules (e.g., stage entry criteria, next step required, close date change limits, stale opp detection) and show how automation enforces them without relying on rep discipline.

opportunities.title: The Death of Third-Party Cookies Isn’t the Story—Identity Resolution in Your CRM Is
opportunities.angle: The real impact of privacy changes is internal: fragmented identities across product, marketing, and sales systems. Explain how to build reliable identity resolution (account matching, contact stitching, domain logic) to keep pipeline reporting credible.

packages.title: AI in RevOps Without the Data Hangover: Safe Wins, Red Flags, and a Governance Line in the Sand
Stop Buying “One More Tool”: A 30-Min RevOps ROI Scorecard to Consolidate, Integrate, or Retire
Stop Silent Automation Failures: Ship a RevOps Data Contract for Leads, Accounts & Opportunities

variants.body_preview: If your AI can write to your CRM, you don’t have “automation.” You have an incident waiting to happe

Hot take: AI shouldn’t write to your CRM (yet). Use it to *propose + audit*, not execute.
